\documentclass[american]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}
\usepackage{amssymb}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
The owner solves the following problem

\[
v_{}^{b}(\theta_{w},\theta_{b},a_{})=\max_{c,a^{\prime},n,k}U(c)+\beta\mathbb{E}_{\left(\theta_{w},\theta_{b}\right)}\left[v\left(\theta_{w}^{\prime},\theta_{b}^{\prime},\eta^{\prime},a^{\prime}\right)\right]
\]
subject to 
\[
c+a^{\prime}\leq Ra+\pi\left(\theta_{b},n,k\right)
\]
where $\pi\left(\theta_{b},n,k\right)=\theta_{b}k^{\alpha}n^{\nu}-R^{k}k-Wn$
and we have two constraints
\[
a^{\prime}\ge0
\]
\[
k\leq\chi a^{\prime}
\]
Let $\mu_{b}$ and $\mu_{c}$ be the multipliers on the borrowing
and collateral constraints and $\lambda$ on the period budget constraint.

The optimality conditions are {[}check signs{]}
\[
U_{c}(c)=\lambda
\]
\[
\beta\mathbb{E}_{\left(\theta_{w},\theta_{b}\right)}\left[v_{a}\left(\theta_{w}^{\prime},\theta_{b}^{\prime},\eta^{\prime},a^{\prime}\right)\right]+\mu_{b}+\chi\mu_{c}=\lambda
\]
\[
\nu\theta_{b}k^{\alpha}n^{\nu}=Wn
\]
\[
\lambda\left[\frac{\alpha\theta_{b}k^{\alpha}n^{\nu}}{k}-R^{k}\right]=\mu_{c}
\]
with complemantary slackness and non-negativity for the multipliers. 

We can substitute out $\lambda$ and $\mu_{c}$ to get 
\[
\beta\mathbb{E}_{\left(\theta_{w},\theta_{b}\right)}\left[v_{a}\left(\theta_{w}^{\prime},\theta_{b}^{\prime},\eta^{\prime},a^{\prime}\right)\right]+\mu_{b}=U_{c}(c)\left[1-\chi\left(\frac{\alpha\theta_{b}k^{\alpha}N\left(k,\theta_{b},W\right)^{\nu}}{k}-R^{k}\right)\right]
\]
Before we do EGM some useful things to note
\begin{itemize}
\item when the borrowing constraint binds, $a^{\prime}=0$, then the agent
cannot rent capital and business profits are zero. Suppose that the
owner is in a situation where $a^{\prime}=0$. The owner could borrow
a little, buy a little bit capital and make positive profit and consume
plus save a part of the profit as collateral for the loan. This is
feasible and will increase consumption. So effectively the borrowing
constraint is really $k\leq\chi a^{\prime}$ 
\item when the borrowing constraint does not bind, $\mu_{b}=0$, we can
back out consumption today given $a^{\prime}$using the previous equation
by setiing $k\left(a^{\prime},\theta_{b}\right)=\min\left\{ \chi a^{\prime},k^{*}\left(\theta_{b},R^{k}\right)\right\} .$
\end{itemize}
Now we can do the EGM. 
\begin{itemize}
\item precompute $k\left(a^{\prime},\theta_{b}\right),$$k^{*}\left(\theta_{b},R^{k}\right)$
and $N\left(k\left(a^{\prime},\theta_{b}\right),\theta_{b},W\right)$.
\item Start with a grid on $a^{\prime}$
\item Compute the candidate solutions $a\left(a^{\prime};\theta_{b},\theta_{a}\right)$
and $c\left(a^{\prime};\theta_{b},\theta_{a}\right)$ that satisfy
the EE equation ignoring the borrowing constraint and we can interpolate
using $\left\{ a\left(a^{\prime};\theta_{b},\theta_{a}\right),c\left(a^{\prime};\theta_{b},\theta_{a}\right)\right\} _{a^{\prime}>0}.$ 
\item There are couple of things we need to be careful with during numerical
implementation. These things wont happen in a simulation because of
inada issues.
\begin{itemize}
\item $1-\chi\left(\frac{\alpha\theta_{b}k\left(a^{\prime},\theta_{b}\right)^{\alpha}N\left(k\left(a^{\prime},\theta_{b}\right),\theta_{b},W\right)^{\nu}}{k}-R^{k}\right)>0$
\end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\end{document}
